  1. Linear Independence and Span

Linear Independence and Span

On this page

  • 1 Conceptual Overview
    • 1.1 Linear Independence
    • 1.2 Span of a Set of Vectors
  • 2 Common Misconceptions
  • 3 Worked Examples
    • 3.1 Basic Examples
      • 3.1.1 Testing for Linear Independence
      • 3.1.2 Finding the Span
    • 3.2 Advanced Examples
      • 3.2.1 Basis Selection
  • 4 Interactive Elements
  • 5 Connections to Other Topics
  • 6 Summary

1 Conceptual Overview

1.1 Linear Independence

  • Definition: A set of vectors is linearly independent if no vector in the set can be written as a linear combination of the others. Mathematically, vectors ( _1, _2, , _n ) are independent if the equation ( c_1_1 + c_2_2 + + c_n_n = 0 ) only has the trivial solution ( c_1 = c_2 = = c_n = 0 ).
  • Importance: Independence is crucial for defining bases, understanding dimension, and ensuring minimality in spanning sets.
  • Geometric Interpretation: In ( ^3 ), three linearly independent vectors span the entire space, while fewer vectors (e.g., two) only span a subspace (e.g., a plane).

1.2 Span of a Set of Vectors

  • Definition: The span of a set of vectors is the collection of all linear combinations of those vectors. If vectors ( _1, _2, , _n ) span a space ( V ), then any vector in ( V ) can be expressed as ( c_1_1 + c_2_2 + + c_n_n ) for some scalars ( c_1, c_2, , c_n ).
  • Relation to Vector Spaces: A spanning set that is also linearly independent forms a basis for the space, providing both coverage and minimality.

2 Common Misconceptions

  • Confusing Linear Independence with Span: Students often assume that spanning implies independence, but a spanning set can contain redundant (dependent) vectors.
  • Interpreting Basis Properties: Not every spanning set is a basis. A basis must also be linearly independent, meaning it has no “extra” vectors that could be written as combinations of others.

3 Worked Examples

3.1 Basic Examples

3.1.1 Testing for Linear Independence

Consider vectors ( _1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix} ) and ( _2 = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} ). To check independence, we solve for scalars ( c_1 ) and ( c_2 ) such that: [ c_1_1 + c_2_2 = . ] Substituting values, we get: [ c_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}
  • c_2 \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} , ] leading to ( c_1 + 2c_2 = 0 ) and ( 2c_1 + 4c_2 = 0 ). These equations imply ( c_1 = -2c_2 ), meaning the only solution is trivial if ( c_1 = c_2 = 0 ), proving the vectors are dependent.

3.1.2 Finding the Span

For vectors ( _1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} ) and ( _2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} ), their span is all of ( ^2 ) since any vector ( = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}

) can be written as ( x_1 + y_2 ).

3.2 Advanced Examples

3.2.1 Basis Selection

In ( ^3 ), find a basis for the subspace spanned by ( \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} ), ( \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \\ 6 \end{bmatrix} ), and ( \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} ). Notice that the first two vectors are linearly dependent, so a basis can be ( { \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} , \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}

} ).

4 Interactive Elements

  • Self-Check Questions: Practice with determining independence and span.
  • Visualization: Use visuals of vector span in R²/R³ to show spanning planes and independent directions.

5 Connections to Other Topics

  • Basis and Dimension: Understanding independence and span is foundational for defining bases.
  • Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Eigenvectors associated with distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent.

6 Summary

  • Linear Independence: No vector in the set can be written as a linear combination of others.
  • Span: All possible combinations of a set of vectors; if they span the space and are independent, they form a basis.
  • Key Formula: Independence implies the number of vectors in a basis is the dimension of the space.
